Running Title: Nano-encapsulation of vitamins 3 Iman Katouzian1,3, Seid Mahdi Jafari1,2,3* 4 1Department of Food Materials and Process Design Engineering, Faculty of Food Technology, University of 5 Agricultural Science and Natural Resources, Gorgan, Iran. 6 2Cereals Health Research Center, Golestan University of Medical Sciences, Gorgan, Iran. 7 3Nano-encapsulation in the Food, Nutraceutical, and Pharmaceutical Industries Group (NFNPIG), Universal 8 Scientific Education and Research Network (USERN), Tehran, Iran 9
*Corrseponding author at Pishro Food Technology Research Group, Gorgan, Iran: 10 Tel./fax: +98 17 324 26 432. E-mail address: smjafari@gau.ac.ir (S.M. Jafari). 11 Structural abstract 12 Background 13 Vitamins are bioactive molecules necessary for human health, which are sensible to degradation. During 14 consumption, the bioavailability of these compounds might be limited due to structure break-down and low 15 absorption. Today, nanoencapsulation can be a promising approach for targeted delivery of vitamins and 16 protecting these bioactive components against destructive environment during processing and delivery. 17 Regarding the benefits of utilizing nanotechnology in the food sector, safety aspects of these tiny carriers 18 should also be clarified as this technology develops. Due to the possible negative effects of nanomaterials, 19 several agencies have legislated regulatory policies to prevent potential harms to the consumers, which are 20 underlined in this article. 21 Scope and approach 22 Nanoencapsulation-based technologies are a unique and novel field of investigation in the food and 23 pharmaceutical industry with benefits, such as higher bioavailability, high shelf-stability and controlled release 24 of active compounds. This review highlights recent works on these techniques and advances made in 25 nanoencapsulation of lipophilic and hydrophilic vitamins, safety issues and health risks regarding the 26 consumption of these products, which opens new horizons in food technology and nutrition with possibilities 27 of commercialization in the near future. 28 Key findings and conclusions 29 Recently, considerable progresses are being carried out in the field of food nanoencapsulation involving novel 30 nanovehicles to encapsulate vitamins. Nanofibers and nanohydrogels are some examples of efficient and 31 modern nanocarriers. Overall, the vitamins encapsulated within nanovehicles are considered safe since they 32 are mostly produced from food components, meanwhile more studies should be performed regarding the 33 safety issues of nanodelivery of vitamins. In near future, it is assumed that nanoencapsulated vitamins will be 34 broadly applied the in the food and beverage products. 35 Keywords: Nanoencapsulation; vitamins; food industry; safety; bioavailability. 36

1. Introduction 37 Vitamins and antioxidants are rudimentary elements for human health as they assist the body to grow and 38 develop. Furthermore, they are able to prevent diseases and to promote general health. Unfortunately, most 39 of these bioactive agents are either produced in trifle amounts or not made in the body. Thus, vitamins need 40 to be supplied from food products and through dietary supplements if needed (Wildman, Wildman, & 41 Wallace, 2006). Some of the beneficial functions of vitamins are as follows: enhancing the immune system 42 and vision, supporting skin health and cell growth and helping to prevent cancer (vitamin A); empowering 43 the immune system, alleviate anxiety and depression, reduce stroke risk and relieve PMS (premenstrual 44 syndrome) (vitamin B-complex); raising immunity, treating common cold symptoms, maintaining healthy 45 skin, healing wounds, reducing cholesterol levels and regulating the blood sugar level, reducing neurological 46 disorders (vitamin C)(Hickey, 2009), preventing cancer and cardiovascular diseases as well as promoting 47 vigorous bones and teeth (vitamin D), restraining brain and nervous system diseases; such as, Alzheimer and 48 other dementias, boosting physical endurance and avoiding skin disorders (vitamin E), helping blood clot, 49 nerve signaling, improving bone health and regulating cellular functions (Zempleni, Suttie, Gregory III, & 50 Stover, 2013). 51 Vitamins are sensitive molecules; therefore they should be preserved from harmful agents like heat and 52 oxidants. Encapsulation is a promising and novel method for preserving the innate characteristics of vitamins 53 over time (Sanguansri & Augustin, 2006). This process includes coating or trapping a biomaterial or a 54 combination into another element. The entrapped substance is normally a liquid, while a gas or solid state 55 substance can also be carried. The coating substance is known as capsule, wall material, membrane, or 56 carrier. 57 Our body has nanoscale structures like DNA, amino acids, etc. (Weiss, Takhistov, & McClements, 2006). 58 Considering these natural nanoparticles, scientists have engineered nanomaterials for the usage in human’s 59 food and recently, there has been a tremendous progress in food nanoencapsulation. 60 In this study, after a brief review on pros and cons of food nanotechnology and microencapsulation of 61 vitamins, we will highlight recent fundamental and novel techniques used to nanoencapsulate different 62 vitamins in the food industry. Besides, issues on the characterization, controlled release and safety-63 consumption of these vital elements are described. Future trends will also be explained in the last section. 64 2. Pros and cons of applying nanotechnology in the food industry 65 Today, the entry of nanotechnology within the food sector has brought new hopes and is expected to be the 66 key to food industry’s concerns as it may bring various benefits, nevertheless like the other emerging 67 technologies it could also have risks for consumers. According to Aguilera (cited in Yaktine & Pray, 2009), 68 exerting nanotechnology in food industry may bring about various advantages and opportunities; such as, 69 developing promising nano-processes, fabricating eco-friendly processes and intelligent nano-packaging, 70 manufacturing products with desirable texture and tastes, producing low-calorie food and beverage products 71

with the aim of changing the lifestyles into healthy ones. He also suggested that there are still more 72 opportunities which will be accomplished by carefully studying how food components are formed, 73 disintegrated, ingested and absorbed and without this perception it wouldn’t be possible to overcome the 74 potential risks and uncertainties within this technology. 75 Regarding the risks and disadvantages of applying nanotechnology in food industry, most of the 76 nanoparticles enter the gut through oral administration and absorption via intestine cells (enterocytes) is 77 designed in a way that they do not allow large or foreign particles to pass through them, nevertheless the 78 nano-sized ingredients are able to cross these barriers, therefore there is a potential risk in bringing up gastric 79 diseases which should investigated through in vivo and clinical studies. 80 3. Microencapsulation vs. nanoencapsulation of vitamins 81 Micro/nanoencapsulation is defined as the creation of a barrier to inhibit unfavorable chemical interactions 82 and for the controlled release of bioactive ingredients especially vitamins. Importance of using the 83 microencapsulation processes for vitamins and their key features could be summarized as below: 84
• Protection of vitamins from external environment • Controlled release of vitamins • Improved flow properties • Reduce overages • Measuring the precise level of vitamin delivery • Forming Light-scattering vitamin solutions • Being cost effective especially for spray drying method • Undesirable flavor of some vitamins are masked • Enriching the food products with a complex of vitamins
While for nano-encapsulation of vitamins, the following advantages can be mentioned: 85
Faster dissociation Higher surface area compared to mass proportion High intracellular uptake Pass along the smallest body fenestrations Enable precision targeting Reduce the reactions between vitmains and other molecules plus surrounding medium Formulating optically transparent vitamin solutions Reduction in the quantity of utilized core-shell material Rendering long-shelf life coated vitamins Reinforced physical stability against coalescence and gravitational separations

The capsule size in microencapsulation ranges between 5-300µm in diameter (F. Gibbs, 1999). When the 87 particle size reduces to the nanoscale during nanoencapsulation, surface-to-volume ratio increases. 88 Therefore, the reactions are speeded by many folds; moreover, the mechanical, optical and electrical 89 properties of the materials will also change (Neethirajan & Jayas, 2011). Physicochemical characteristics of 90 vitamins strongly depend on the applied nanoencapsulation approach and delivery system. Thus, an 91 appropriate nanoencapsulation technique must be chosen considering the required size, physicochemical 92 properties, nature of the encapsulated vitamin and the wall material. Nanoencapsulation process is more 93 complex than microencapsulation because of the difficulty in acquiring an intricate morphology for the 94 capsule entrapping the vitamin (Chau, Wu, & Yen, 2007). 95 According to Gutiérrez, et al., (2013) casein nanoparticles were found to be more stable, cost efficient and 96 environmentally friendly when compared with microemulsions. Moreover, Danino, Livney, Ramon, Portnoy, 97 & Cogan, (2014) and Semo, Kesselman, Danino, & Livney, (2007) suggested that nanoencapsulation via ẞ-98 cyclodextrins produced satisfactory sensory properties and created optically transparent solutions, however, 99 microemulsions tend to scatter light. In a recent investigation, it was suggested that nanoliposomes have the 100 benefits to minimize the reactions between bioactives and other molecules, increasing the shelf-life of food 101 products and reducing the amount of used core-shell material compared to conventional liposomes, which are 102 biocompatible and their surface is easily modified (Fathima, Fathima, Abhishek, & Khanum, 2016). 103 Fig. 1 presents the forms of microcapsuls. The shell is responsible for protecting vitamins from water, 104 oxygen or sunlight. On the other hand, nanostructured delivery forms applied in nanoencapsulation of 105 vitamins are summarized in Fig. 2. 106 Fig. 1 107 Fig. 2 108 There are some commercially approved biopolymers for the encapsulation of vitamins. Starches and 109 cyclodextrins are carbohydrate-based biopolymers that protect these sensitive compounds from the outside 110 environment. Gum Arabic is also used in microencapsulating according to its solubility, viscosity and 111 emulsification features. However, economically it is not profitable. Alginates can also be used as a wall 112 material at environment temperatures. Ethylcellulose has been approved to be a good substance for 113 encapsulating water-soluble vitamins, because as the wall materials width rises, the water permeability of the 114 dispersed vitamins is reduced. Protein based shells may also be utilized in encapsulating different vitamins. 115 Nevertheless, their high cost is limiting factor for using them in an industrial scale. 116 4. Conventional microencapsulation techniques of vitamins 117 Before explaining the recent nanoencapsulation techniques applied in protection of vitamins, it is necessary 118 to be familiar with common microencapsulation methods used for different vitamins. Table 1 summarizes the 119 works performed on the microencapsulation of vitamins. In this section, some of the most important 120 techniques plus the literatures are presented. 121

Table 1 122 4. 1 Spray-drying 123 It is one of the oldest encapsulation methods capable of producing encapsulated powders with different 124 particle sizes mostly utilized for encapsulating lipo-soluble vitamins in an industrial scale (Jafari, He, & 125 Bhandari, 2007a). In this procedure, all matrix substances; like, Arabic gum and maltodextrin are drenched 126 and the oil-based material is added during mixing. Later, homogenization is used to achieve an emulsion and 127 finally the yield powder is achieved through spray-drying process. The resulting powder contains 1-50% 128 (w/w) oil (Boyle & Chang, 1999). These microencapsulated vitamins are commonly used in tablets in which 129 oxidation stability and tablet properties are affected by the type of the matrix material. (Shi & Tan, 2002) 130 trapped vitamin D2 in a chitosan/ethylcellulose coating, and then examined morphology and release traits of 131 the capsuls. In vitro results showed that microcapsuls are able to remain unchanged in the intestine juice. 132 High-DE maltodextrins are hygroscopic, thus the produced powder is not desirable. A maltodextrin with a 133 25DE combined with lactose, galactose or glucose has been shown to extend the shelf life of encapsulated 134 trans-ẞ-carotene compared with commercial 25 DE maltodextrin alone (Desobry, Netto, & Labuza, 1999). 135 Spray drying has also been applied for encapsulation of water-soluble vitamins too. For example, Ascorbic 136 acid (vitamin C) is an antioxidant or vitamin supplement vastly used in the food and beverage industry, 137 which is so unstable and can be degraded by many mechanisms (Kirby, Whittle, Rigby, Coxon, & Law, 138 1991). (Desai & Park, 2005) analyzed the encapsulation of vitamin C regarding trypolyphosphate cross-139 linked chitosan microspheres as the wall material. As a result, cross-linking factor influenced the particle size 140 between 6.1-9µm. 141 4.2 Spray chilling and spray cooling 142 Both techniques involve diffusing the vitamins in a molten fat or wax. Next, this dispersion is atomized 143 through heated nozzles into a case at room temperature (spray-cooling) or low temperatures (spray-chilling). 144 At the room temperature, the melting point of the encapsulated material is between 45-122°C. At low 145 temperatures (refrigerate temperature), substances tend to melt at 32-42°C (Risch & Reineccius, 1995). 146 These microcapsuls won’t dissolve in water and as the temperature rises, the fat or wax membrane will be 147 molten. Thus, the fat-crystallization in the spray- chilling or cooling process needs to be monitored carefully. 148 This is a suitable technique for encapsulating lipid-soluble vitamins. (Wegmüller, Zimmermann, Bühr, 149 Windhab, & Hurrell, 2006) microencapsulated iron, vitamin A and iodine in hydrogenated palm fat by spray 150 cooling. After 6 months, an excellent stability of retinyl palmitate was observed and losses occurred during 151 this period was nearly 12%. 152 4.3 Emulsion technique 153 This process includes dispersing vitamins into an immiscible liquid phase, which possesses the shell 154 material. Second, adjustments are made in order to form shells around the scattered vitamins in the solution. 155 O/W is the most prevalent two phase system applied in encapsulation. (Wang, MacGillivray, & Macartney, 156

2009) encapsulated cob (III) alamins; like, CNCbl and AdoCbl with 5,6dimethylbenzimidazole and 157 cucurbituril. The cucurbituril combined with vitamin B12 imitate the applications of chemical, photochemical 158 and electrochemical of these and other cob (III) alamins. (Leonard, Good, Gugger, & Traber, 2004) 159 encapsulated vitamin E in a breakfast cereal and compared its bioavailability to vitamin E encapsulated in 160 supplements. The capsule was made from d9-α-tocopheryl acetate (400-IU capsule). Results showed that 161 encapsulated vitamin E in supplements are poorly absorbed; however the bioavailability is increased by 162 using it in fortified-foods. (Van Hasselt, et al., 2009) used polymeric micelles to encapsulate vitamin K. They 163 compared the capsule´s absorption in bile duct legated and sham rats. As a result, the gastrointestinal 164 absorption of the microcapsuls was affected through free bile, furthermore the uptake of micelles via 165 pinocytosis was considered inconsiderable. 166 4.4 Fluidized bed coating 167 It is also known as air suspension coating. Solid particles are suspended in an upward moving flow of air 168 which can be either cool or hot. Afterwards, the solid particles are sprayed through the top of the atomized 169 particles of coating wall material, which can be molten or dissolved in an evaporable solvent (Risch & 170 Reineccius, 1995). The coating’s material can be cellulose derivatives, dextrins, emulsifiers, lipids, protein 171 derivatives and starch derivatives. This method is prevalent in nutritional supplements that contain 172 encapsulated versions of vitamin C, vitamin B complex and a variety of vitamin/mineral premixes. 173 Moreover, it can be consumed in a variety of food products including: seasonings, fillings, desserts and 174 puddings (Risch & Reineccius, 1995). (Xie, et al., 2010) reported encapsulation of vitamin C using this 175 method with the use of gelatin as the wall material. They fed larval shrimps (Penaeus japonicas) with this 176 micro-diet; as a result the wet weight of shrimps rose 300% in 10 to 30 days after hatching. The retention 177 efficiency of vitamin C estimated 88.2% in the coating procedure. 178 4.5 Liposome entrapment 179 Liposomes can be defined as single or multi-layered vesicles, which include the complete entrapment of an 180 aqueous phase in a phospholipid-based membrane. Aqueous or lipid-soluble vitamins, but not both are 181 encapsulated in these membranes. (Kirby, et al., 1991) encapsulated vitamin C with high efficiency using this 182 technique. The most stable liposomes are made of lecithin, cholesterol and negatively charged phospholipids. 183 A prevalent method for producing liposomes is dehydration-rehydration and no organic solvents are used. 184 4.6 Coacervation 185 In this method, the liquid phase of coating material is separated from a polymeric solution, and the phase is 186 wrapped around the core particles as a uniform layer (F. Gibbs, 1999). It encompasses the dissolving gelling 187 protein and the emulsification of the core compound into the protein. The liquid coating is separated from the 188 polymer solution and is used to cover the material to be encapsulated through controlled physical mixing. It 189 is solidified by thermal, cross-linking or de-solvation methods. Finally, the microcapsuls are obtained by 190 centrifugation or filtration and the results are discrete particles. Coacervation can be simple or complex. The 191

former, contains merely one colloidal solute like gelatin. The latter, is obtained through the usage of a second 192 oppositely charged hydrophilic colloid such as gelatin and gum acacia or gelatin and polysaccharide (F. 193 Gibbs, 1999). (Junyaprasert, Mitrevej, Sinchaipanid, Boonme, & Wurster, 2001) investigated the effect of 194 process variables on microencapsulating vitamin A palmitate via complex coacervation with gelatin and 195 acacia. 196 5. Nanoencapsulation technologies applied on different vitamins 197 According to the recent studies in the field of nanoencapsulation of vitamins, it is expected that in future the 198 novel nanoencapsulation techniques seek to (1) employ naturally occurring food components for encasing 199 bioactives especially vitamins (Chapeau, et al., 2016; David & Livney, 2016; Lee, et al., 2016; Santiago & 200 Castro, 2016), (2) fabricating novel and efficient nanovehicles by the combination of biopolymers, 201 manufacturing nanocomposites, modifying the nanocarriers (Assadpour, Maghsoudlou, Jafari, Ghorbani, & 202 Aalami, 2016; Bochicchio, Barba, Grassi, & Lamberti, 2016; Chapeau, et al., 2016; Lee, et al., 2016; Tan, 203 Feng, Zhang, Xia, & Xia, 2016), (3) exerting novel low energy methods such as, spontaneous emulsification 204 rather than high energy preparation approaches to retain bioactives against harsh processing conditions, 205 decline the surfactant and eliminate the cosurfactant (Assadpour, et al., 2016; Dasgupta, Ranjan, Mundra, 206 Ramalingam, & Kumar, 2016; Mehrnia, Jafari, Makhmal-Zadeh, & Maghsoudlou, 2016) and (4) using novel 207 computational and numerical methods like Monte-Carlo simulations to predict the release profile and 208 optimize targeted delivery of bioactive compounds (Dan, 2016; H. H. Liu, Surawanvijit, Orkoulas, & Cohen, 209 2016; Malik, Genzer, & Hall, 2015). 210 In this section, novel methods for nanoencapsulating vitamins are explained. Table 2 and 3 represents 211 different approaches used for nanoencapsulating hydrophilic and lipophilic vitamins, respectively. 212 Table 2 213 Table 3 214 5.1 Nanoemulsification methods 215 Most prevalent uses of emulsion technology are in aqueous solutions, and nanoemulsions are produced in 216 this medium. Nanoemulsion droplet sizes ranges between 50 to 1000 nm (Sanguansri & Augustin, 2006). 217 There are two ways to prepare nanoemulsions; low energy and high energy techniques such as phase 218 inversion temperature and microfluidization respectively. Nanoemulsions can be used in the liquid state; 219 meanwhile a spray-drying process will be performed to obtain the powder form of the encapsulated material 220 (Jafari, He, & Bhandari, 2007b). Furthermore, it is possible to increase the stability and encapsulation 221 efficiency of the bioactive compounds via multiple emulsions containing a complex of biopolymers 222 (Mohammadi, Jafari, Assadpour, & Esfanjani, 2015). 223 Different vitamins can be encapsulated and transmitted via nanoemulsions (Gonnet, Lethuaut, & Boury, 224 2010; Mohammadi, et al., 2015). For instance, (Cho, Seo, Yim, & Lee, 2013) stated that nanoencapsulation 225 of thiamine dilauryl sulfate (TDS), a vitamin B derivative encased with lecithin as an edible encapsulant, 226

restricted the spore germination of Fusarium oxypansum f.sp. Moreover, this compound obstructed its 227 mycelial growth. 228 There has been some studies in the area of natural surfactants. For instance, (Ozturk, Argin, Ozilgen, & 229 McClements, 2014) encapsulated vitamin D3 in O/W emulsions with quillaja saponin as a natural surfactant. 230 In the experiment bioacessiblity of vitamin D3 declined in the following order: corn oil≈ fish oil ˃ orange oil 231 ˃ mineral oil ˃ medium chain triglycerids (MCT). Long chain triglycerids (corn or fish oil) was considered 232 the optimum compound, which enhance the vitamin bioaccessibility. 233 Double emulsions can be another form of nanoencapsulation of bioactive ingredients (Esfanjani, Jafari, 234 Assadpoor, & Mohammadi, 2015; Mohammadi, et al., 2015). (Bou, Cofrades, & Jiménez-Colmenero, 2014) 235 assessed the physicochemical properties of riboflavin, encapsulated in food-grade W1/O/W2 double 236 emulsions with different types of lipid sources (chia oil, sunflower oil, olive oil or rendered pork backfat). 237 Riboflavin was effectively encapsulated in chia oil at start, nevertheless the double emulsions in rendered 238 pork backfat protected vitamin B2 more efficiently after 8 days at 4 °C. All in all, double emulsions were 239 stable to the stresses that normally exist in the food industry. 240 (Hategekimana, Chamba, Shoemaker, Majeed, & Zhong, 2015; Hategekimana, Masamba, Ma, & Zhong, 241 2015) produced vitamin E- loaded nanocapsuls by octenyl succinic anhydride starches as emulsifiers and 242 wall materials and then stabilized them via spray-drying method. High degree of substitution, low molecular 243 weight and low interfacial tension improved emulsification properties, whereas oxygen permeability and 244 water vapor permeability influenced the film forming characteristics. The degradation profile of vitamin E 245 was best fitted with Weibull model. Overall, low molecular weights formed stable vitamin E nanocapsuls, 246 which can be applied in drug and beverage sector. 247 (Saberi, Fang, & McClements, 2013) fabricated vitamin E-enriched nanoemulsions via spontaneous 248 emulsification. It can be defined as the formation of little oil droplets when an oil/surfactant mixture is 249 titrated in an aqueous solution. When 30% propylene glycol (PG) or 20% ethanol was present in the aqueous 250 phase, the smallest droplets (d<50nm) and highest transparency were acquired. However, Ostwald ripening 251 occurred as nanoemulsions were unstable during storage especially at high temperatures. Undiluted 252 nanoemulsions showed a high and irreversible increase in turbidity upon heating (53°C) for the system with 253 30% PG and 38°C for the one containing 20% ethanol. Considering diluted compounds, a much better 254 thermal stability with a high rate in turbidity at 75.5 °C for both systems. The release criteria of poorly water-255 soluble active vitamin E acetate from oil/water nanoemulsions was reported by (Morais & Burgess, 2014), 256 which used a low energy emulsification method. Nanoemulsions consisted of canola oil, cremophorRH40® 257 and span80®. Dialysis sac and reverse dialysis sac techniques were carried out as well as USP1 dissolution 258 apparatus fitted with dialysis sac adapters to measure the vitamin E release. Micellar solubilization increased 259 vitamin E transport from canola oil to buffer solution; however no concentration active increase in the 260

nanoemulsion external aqueous phase was seen considering the presence of micelles. (Guttoff, Saberi, & 261 McClements, 2015) prepared vitamin D nanoemulsions through spontaneous emulsification. They 262 investigated the effect of vitamin D and MCT for surfactant to oil ratio, surfactant type (Tween 20,40,60,80 263 and 85) and stirring criteria on the initial particle size of vitamin D. Results showed that small droplet 264 diameters (d<200nm) was produced using Tween at high stirring speeds (800rpm). These systems were 265 unstable to heating (T˃80°C). The thermal stability could be increased by choosing a suitable cosurfactant 266 (sodium dodecyl sulphate). 267 Assadpour, et al., (2016) nano-encapsulated folic acid (vitamin B9) in maltodextrin-whey protein double 268 emulsions via spontaneous emulsification method, which is a low energy technique. They utilized Span 80 as 269 a nonionic surfactant in three phase/surfactant proportions (0.2, 0.6 and 1), moreover the applied folic acid 270 amount was 1.0, 2.0 and 3.0 mg/ml in the dispersed phase. In summary, the formulation containing 3mg/ml 271 folic acid in the 12% dispersed phase and water to surfactant proportion of 0.9 was considered as the 272 optimum sample, thus suggesting that spontaneous technique is beneficial in formulating water in oil 273 nanoemulsions. 274 Dasgupta, et al., (2016) formulated vitamin E acetate nanoemulsions (NE) by edible mustard oil and Tween 275 80 as surfactant. NE was produced via low-energy wash-out technique, in which there is a continuous 276 addition of the water phase to the oil phase and vitamin E acetate. In conclusion, the nanoemulsions 277 (encapsulation efficiency 99.65%) can be used to improve the shelf life of beverages along with their 278 increased antimicrobial and bioavailability characteristics. 279 5.2 Nanoliposomes 280 Hydrophobic/hydrophilic interactions among lipid/lipid and lipid/water interfaces are responsible for the 281 formation of liposomes. Liposomes are formed in single and bilayer arrangements. Lipo-soluble and water-282 soluble vitamins can be entrapped in these nanocarriers for maintaining their stability in different mediums. 283 In a study by (Ma, Kuang, Hao, & Gu, 2009), they inserted vitamin E into nanoliposomes with tea 284 polyphenol (water-soluble). The encapsulation efficiencies reported for hydrophobic and hydrophilic agents 285 were 94% and 50%, respectively. The combined nanoencapsulation of vitamin E with vitamin C has also 286 been carried out (Marsanasco, Márquez, Wagner, Alonso, & Chiaramoni, 2011). Liposome’s structure was 287 influenced by incubation in buffer solution and stomach pH. The higher absorption of the bioactive 288 compound is attributed to the greater bioavailability of vitamin E. 289 (Zhou, et al., 2014) produced a drug delivery system using high methoxyl pectin (HMP) or low methoxyl 290 pectin (LMP) coated with vitamin C liposomes. FTIR and morphology assays demonstrated that the 291 hydrogen binding interactions coated pectin to the vitamin C liposomes. Overall, the skin permeation of 292 vitamin C increased 1.7-fold for HMP-L and 2.1-fold for LMP-L after 1 day respectively, whereas vitamin C 293 nanoliposomes showed a lower number. (N. Liu & Park, 2009) used chitosan-coated nanoparticles made 294

from phosphatidilecholine (pc) and cholesterol (cho) to encase vitamin C. The nanocapsuls contaning pc:cho 295 ratio 60:40 were promising carriers, which had a loading efficiency about 96.5% and a payload of 46.82%. 296 Tan, et al., (2016) employed composite phospholipid-chitosan to coat the nanoliposomes (chitosomes), 297 which entailed carotenoids, lycopene, ẞ-carotene, lutein and canthaxanthin. The composite covered the 298 liposomes via layer self-assembly deposition method. To sum up, the biopolymer-covered nanoliposomes 299 protected lutein and ẞ-carotene to a greater extent compared to canthaxanthin and lycopene. Considering the 300 arrangement of free lipid molecules at the hydrophilic heads and the non-polar membrane core were 301 enhanced, which directly represents the stability of these biopolymer nanoparticles against undesirable 302 conditions; such as, GI stress, etc. Also, Bochicchio, et al., (2016) loaded various vitamins (vitamin E, 303 vitamin B12 and vitamin D2) via nano liposomes including multilamellar large vesicles (MLVs) and small 304 unilamellar vesicles (SUVs). All in all, great encapsulation efficiencies were achieved by both MLVs 305 (between 72% to 95%) and SUVs (between 56% to 76%). 306 5.3 Nanoprecipitation 307 This method is also called solvent displacement. In this process, the organic internal phase containing the 308 dissolved vitamin is emulsified into the aqueous external phase. The precipitation of polymer from an 309 organic solution and the diffusion of the organic solvent in the aqueous medium is occurred in this technique 310 (Galindo-Rodriguez, Allemann, Fessi, & Doelker, 2004). 311 (Khayata, Abdelwahed, Chehna, Charcosset, & Fessi, 2012) produced vitamin E-loaded nanocapsuls via 312 nanoprecipitation technique at laboratory and pilot-scale. The effect of several formulation variables was 313 investigated on the nanocapsuls properties (mean diameter, zeta potential and entrapment efficiency). The 314 optimized formulation of the vitamin E-loaded nanocapsule at laboratory and pilot-scale had the mean 315 diameter of 165 and 172 nm, respectively with a high entrapment rate (98% and 97%, respectively). 316 (Duclairoir, Orecchioni, Depraetere, & Nakache, 2002) encapsulated vitamin E in the matrix of protein 317 fractions of wheat gluten (gliadins). They co-precipitated aqueous ethanolic solution of vitamin E and gliadin 318 in water. 319 Emulsification-solvent evaporation is an improved sort of solvent evaporation technique which includes 320 emulsification of the polymer solution into an aqueous. Afterwards, the solvent is evaporated and the 321 polymer precipitation remains as the nanoparticles (Reis, Neufeld, Ribeiro, & Veiga, 2006). The size of the 322 particles can be modified by adjusting the stir rate, type and the amount of dispersing substance, viscosity of 323 the phases and temperature. High-speed homogenization and ultrasonication are applied in order to obtain a 324 small particle size (Dehnad, Mirzaei, Emam-Djomeh, Jafari, & Dadashi, 2014). 325 David & Livney, (2016) engaged potato proteins (Patatin, protease inhibitors and other high molecular 326 weight proteins comprising 40%, 50% and 10% of the whole soluble proteins sequentially) as a natural food-327 based material to protect and deliver vitamin D3 (VD) in model beverage solutions. VD was encapsulated 328 within the protein nanoparticles using the liquid antisolvent precipitation method in which two solvents are 329

employed; one is a good solvent for the bioactive, while the other represents poor solvent activity, finally by 330 adding an antisolvent the bioactive compound is precipitated. To sum up, VD- potato proteins nanocomlexes 331 increased the shelf life of the samples and declined the vitamin loss through pasteurization rendering clear 332 and enriched solutions. 333 5.4 Solid lipid nanoparticles (SLNs) 334 It is a nice alternative for nanodispersions. The nanoparticles are produced through congealing. The vitamins 335 are nanoencapsulated in a solid lipid matrix which has a good stability. Applying an electrical field (103 V/cm), the electric charges will gather on the surface of the droplet. 406 Next, the droplets will be deformed by the electric field and they will form a shape of cone, called the Taylor 407 cone. As the field strength increases, a fluid jet originates under the electric field adjacent to the spinneret tip 408 and moves toward the conductive collector (counter electrode). Whipping and circular movements trigger a 409 fast evaporation of the solvent due to the high surface charge jet under the electric field. After the process, 410 solid thin fibers are acquired in the form of nonwoven mats (Kessick, Fenn, & Tepper, 2004). 411 Electrospraying would be defined liquid atomization applied through electrical forces. The difference 412 between these techniques lies in the solution concentration. With this in mind, for low-concentrated solutions 413 the jet attached to cone is destabilized owing to varicose, then the output is fine particles. On the contrary, if 414 the concentration is high the jet is stabilized and the yield will be elongated fibers by whipping instability 415 procedure (Bhushani & Anandharamakrishnan, 2014). 416 Pérez-Masiá, et al., (2015) successfully applied this technique to nanoencapsulate folic acid, entrapped by 417 whey protein concentrate (WPC) matrix and commercial resistant starch. Characterization methods for nanoencapsulated vitamins 458 The most common ways to determine nanoparticles morphology are cryogenic transmission electron 459 microscopy (cryo-TEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), scanning electron microscopy (SEM) 460 and atomic force microscopy (AFM). Dynamic light scattering (DLS) is extensively used by scientists to 461 specify the size distribution of vitamin nanoparticles. Zeta potential is measured via laser Doppler 462 anemometry. This factor gives us information about the stability and size of nanoparticles in the in vitro 463 environment (Garti, 2008). Considering surface modification of the nanoparticles, Fourier transform infrared 464 spectroscopy (FTIR) is an appropriate method to analyze this feature. High pressure liquid chromatography 465 (HPLC) or spectroscopy at defined wavelengths can be used to determine the quantitative characteristics of 466 entrapped vitamins within nanocapsuls (Garti, 2008). 467

Controlled release of vitamins through nanoencapsulation 475 Degradation of polymeric matrix is responsible for releasing the vitamins (passive release) from 476 micro/nanocapsuls, and dispersing the vitamin throughout the matrix (active release). When the vitamin is 477 released, diffusion of the particles plays an important role in this stage. In this period, the vitamins diffuse in 478 the hydrophilic environment (Dan, 2016). Furthermore, water molecules are dispersed through the 479 nanoparticle matrix. Diffusion rate is closely related to the hydrophilicity of the polymeric matrix. Afterward, 480 the vitamin and the nanocapsuls are eroded gradually (Lamprecht, Schäfer, & Lehr, 2001). Initially the 481 vitamins in the nanoparticles are released fast in reaction to the apt environment (burst effect), followed by a 482 more stationary release rate. The burst effect is advantageous when the high releases strengthen the 483 performance of the active particle or it might be hazardous when a constant release rate is expected. 484 The basic approaches to quantify the release of vitamins are illustrated in Fig 4. The first method (a) uses 485 centrifugation to separate the core material from the nanoparticle suspension; meanwhile the second method 486 (b) uses dialysis or filtration for separation. PBS (phosphate bovine serum) is a common suspension medium, 487 which is applied here. Considering the first method, volume is kept constant by addition of PBS. In the other 488 approach, sample is divided into many sub-samples to study the release profile for the desired period of time. 489 Concentration gradient is kept constant in the second approach for the occurrence of diffusion process. 490 Fig. 3 491 The main factors which influence release profile of vitamins are explained below along with the recent 492 investigations. 493 7.1 Vitamin type and concentration 494 Chemical and physical interactions such as, hydrophilic-hydrophobic interactions, Van der Waals forces, etc. 495 among the vitamin and polymeric matrix influence the release mechanism of the entrapped agent. There are two terms to express the amount of entrapped vitamin. 498 First, the vitamin content is attributed to a mass of vitamins in nanoparticles divided by mass of 499 nanoparticles, expressed in %w/w. An ordinary value for the vitamin quantity ranges between 0.5 to 4% w/w 500 for hydrophilic components, and 10 to 15% w/w for hydrophobic components. Second, the entrapment 501

Safety regulations and risks of nanoencapsulated vitamins 573 Considering food safety, FDA has confirmed the approaches related to the nanotechnology-based food 574 components for mass production (Chau, et al., 2007). However, questions are being posed that the increased 575 bioavailability, uptake and modified biokinetics of the nanosized vitamins might be hazardous to the 576 biological system. It is assumed that biodegradable natural materials which are used for nanoencapsulation 577 are considered low-risk compared to synthesized polymeric nanocapsuls. Until now, ambiguities on 578 consuming nano-scale food materials still exist, besides their effects on human health and environment needs 579 to be further analyzed (Dowling, 2004). 580 Still, there is no certain legislation in which nanomaterials (especially encased vitamins) in food industry are 581 markedly addressed; nevertheless agencies and government insist that current legislations made by them 582 ensure the safety of nano-food products (Amenta, et al., 2015). 583 8.1 An overview of nano regulations in different countries 584 In 2011, a guidance document entitled “Guidance for the risk assessment of the application of nanoscience 585 and nanotechnologies in the food and feed chain” was prepared by The European Food Safety Authority 586 (ESFA). In essence, this guidance provides as assessment for the risks of employing nanomaterials in food 587 products. Nevertheless, considering the physico-chemical properties of the nanomaterials, these minute 588 particles are also needed to be analyzed in five stages: (a) When prepared; (b) for the usage in food product; 589 (c) within the food network; (d) In the toxicity assays; (e) inside the biological fluids and cells. 590 Another important factor, which should be considered, is the interactions occurred between nanomaterials 591 and food structure. Regarding the catalytic function of the nanomaterials, radical oxygens or photoreactions 592 might be formed, thus these factors should be carefully characterized within the nanofood products. 593 According to the EU principle suggested in December 2011 (Amenta, et al., 2015), engineered nanomaterials 594 (ENM) should be mentioned in the label of nano-food products. This legislation was considered to be exerted 595 till in December 2014. Regarding article 2 from this legislation, ENMs are considered to be 100nm or less in 596 one or more dimensions either inside or at the surface moreover aggregates or agglomerates above the size of 597 100nm, which represent the nano characteristics, are also referred as ENMs. 598 The US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) believes that emerging nano-food products can be regulated 599 under its authorities, nevertheless there is not a delicate principle attributed to the nanomaterials within food 600 industry. On the other hand, this organization has prepared a guidance for the manufacturers entitled “Draft 601 Guidance for Industry” regarding the safety and regulatory issues in novel food industry technologies (FDA, 602 2011). This definition of nanomaterials described by this draft guidance is mentioned below: 603 • Agents or products lying within the nanoscale range at least in one dimension (from 1 to 100nm). 604

Conclusions and future trends 649 Nanoencapsulation of vitamins with different techniques is expected to be a crucial field of research in the 650 following years. By entrapping several vitamins in the nanocapsuls, a synergistic effect can be achieved that 651 enriches human food. Techniques like nanoemulsification, coacervation, nanoprecipitation, nanoliposomes 652 and solvent evaporation are enduring methods for nanoencapsulating not only vitamins but also other 653 ingredients. Furthermore, solvent evaporation and nanoprecipitation remains to be exclusive approaches to 654 encapsulate lipophilic vitamins. Nonetheless, all these techniques require suitable drying methods in order to 655 produce nanoencapsulates in the powder form. Today, spray-drying and freeze drying are widely used as 656 drying methods in order to nanoencapsulate the bioactive materials, especially vitamins. The disadvantages 657 of freeze drying and spray-drying are the high costs and changes needed for retaining the nanoparticle size, 658 respectively. Therefore, special apparatuses are required to produce the nano-sized powders. Besides, each 659 encapsulation technique has its own operating characteristics that influence the final nano product. Most of 660 the nanoencapsulated products have represented excellent bioavailability. The release of the vitamins is 661 considerably related to the nanoparticle size among the other physical features, thus many scientists are 662 trying to decline the size of the nanoparticles due to the increase in the surface and better absorption in the 663 epithelial cells. More work need to be done on carefully designing the nanoparticle to interact in the 664 appropriate conditions (i.e. pH, temperature). Challenging questions might come up with this end; like 665 synthesizing novel nanopolymers for optimizing the delivery process. Furthermore, the safety of vitamin 666 nanoencapsulation in food needs further investigation. It includes the complicated interactions among 667 nanoparticles and the cellular system. Finally, the process of the delivery in the reaction site needs to be 668 carefully studied. 669 References 670

ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT Research Highlights
• Importance of vitamin nanoencapsulation is compared to microencapsulation. • Microencapsulation techniques applied in vitamins are discussed. • Nanoencapsulation methods and nanocarriers applied in vitamins are reviewed. • Factors influencing the release rate of vitamins are highlighted. • Safety and risk evaluation issues are analyzed.
